title: The most important century in human history

multiple-choice.question: What is the metric used to determine the most important century in human history?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of wars fought during that century

options.label: B
options.text: The emergence of a major religion

options.label: C
options.text: The moment of great change that shifted humanity's trajectory for centuries to come

options.label: D
options.text: The number of technological advancements made during that century

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated risk of existential catastrophe due to nuclear winter and climate change?
What is the main difference between narrow AI and artificial general intelligence (AGI)?

options.label: A
options.text: Narrow AI is more intelligent than AGI

options.label: B
options.text: AGI is designed to perform a specific task, while narrow AI can adapt to multiple tasks

options.label: C
options.text: Narrow AI is designed to perform a specific task, while AGI can adapt to multiple tasks

options.label: D
options.text: AGI is more limited in its capabilities than narrow AI

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is one possible outcome if an AGI emerges with deep respect for human life and a desire to solve all humanity's troubles?

options.label: A
options.text: The AGI will become a benevolent dictator

options.label: B
options.text: The AGI will lead to a utopian society

options.label: C
options.text: The AGI's strict values might become hegemonic, locking humanity into one ideology

options.label: D
options.text: The AGI will become a tool for human domination

multiple-choice.question: What is the main message of the transcript regarding the importance of the current century?

options.label: A
options.text: The current century is not important because it is just a continuation of previous centuries

options.label: B
options.text: The current century is the most important century in human history

options.label: C
options.text: The decisions made in the current century might have a major impact on humanity's future

options.label: D
options.text: The current century is not important because it is too early to tell

title: When you're an ant but also a fungus tycoon - Charles Wallace

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the fungus that leafcutter ants farm?

options.label: A
options.text: It is genetically identical to its wild relatives.

options.label: B
options.text: It can survive without the help of the leafcutter ants.

options.label: C
options.text: It provides the ants with an essential amino acid and digestive enzymes.

options.label: D
options.text: It is genetically distinct from its wild relatives and can no longer survive without the ants' help.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the smallest ants in the leafcutter colony?

options.label: A
options.text: They forage for leaves and bring them back to the nest.

options.label: B
options.text: They guard the nest from predators.

options.label: C
options.text: They clean the leaf fragments of debris and pathogens.

options.label: D
options.text: They tend to the fungal gardens.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the pheromones on the trails created by the foragers?

options.label: A
options.text: To attract predators to the nest.

options.label: B
options.text: To mark the trails as efficient highways.

options.label: C
options.text: To communicate with other colonies.

options.label: D
options.text: To repel intruders.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the tiny cockroaches and the leafcutter ants?

options.label: A
options.text: The cockroaches are predators of the ants.

options.label: B
options.text: The cockroaches are prey for the ants.

options.label: C
options.text: The cockroaches feed opportunistically off the fungus and hitch rides on soon-to-be queens.

options.label: D
options.text: The cockroaches are competitors of the ants for food.

multiple-choice.question: What is the threat posed by the parasitic micro-fungus Escovopsis to the leafcutter colony?

options.label: A
options.text: It would destroy the fungal gardens and the ants and cockroaches that depend on them.

options.label: B
options.text: It would reduce the colony's foraging efficiency.

options.label: C
options.text: It would increase the colony's susceptibility to predators.

options.label: D
options.text: It would decrease the colony's ability to produce pheromones.

title: The man who lost his sense of touch - Antonio Cataldo

multiple-choice.question: What was Ian Waterman diagnosed with after collapsing from a severe case of gastric flu?

options.label: A
options.text: A rare form of paralysis

options.label: B
options.text: A severe case of neuropathy

options.label: C
options.text: A rare and extreme form of deafferentation

options.label: D
options.text: A neurological disorder causing muscle weakness

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of mechanoreceptors in the somatosensory system?

options.label: A
options.text: To sense pain

options.label: B
options.text: To sense temperature changes

options.label: C
options.text: To sense mechanical deformation of the skin

options.label: D
options.text: To sense proprioception

options.label: A
options.text: Temporary relief from pain

options.label: B
options.text: Increased sensitivity to pain

options.label: C
options.text: Permanent loss of sensation

options.label: D
options.text: Dull, aching pain

multiple-choice.question: What is the condition known as "touch starvation" characterized by?

options.label: A
options.text: Anxiety, depression, and high blood pressure

options.label: B
options.text: Weakened immune system and social isolation

options.label: C
options.text: Loss of tactile sensations and proprioception

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of propriocepters in the somatosensory system?

options.label: A
options.text: To sense pain

options.label: B
options.text: To sense temperature changes

options.label: C
options.text: To sense mechanical deformation of the skin

options.label: D
options.text: To detect and relay information about the position of the body

title: How do airplanes actually fly? - Raymond Adkins

options.text: It was too heavy

options.label: B
options.text: It was based on an incomplete theory of flight

options.label: C
options.text: It was not curved enough

options.label: D
options.text: It was too small

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Thrust

options.label: C
options.text: Lift

options.label: D
options.text: Drag

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the main reason why the "Longer Path" or "Equal Transit Time" explanation of lift is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Air molecules above and below the wing need to meet back up

options.label: B
options.text: Air molecules above and below the wing don't need to meet back up

options.label: C
options.text: The wing is not curved enough

options.label: D
options.text: The air is too dense

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the air flowing across the upper surface of the wing as it moves forward?

options.label: A
options.text: It slows down and increases in pressure

options.label: B
options.text: It speeds up and decreases in pressure

options.label: C
options.text: It remains the same speed and pressure

options.label: D
options.text: It becomes turbulent

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the set of formulas used by engineers to precisely model air's flow around a wing and detail how lift is generated?

options.label: A
options.text: Navier-Stokes equations

options.label: B
options.text: Bernoulli's principle

options.label: C
options.text: Newton's laws

options.label: D
options.text: Einstein's theory

title: History vs. Thomas Jefferson - Frank Cogliano

multiple-choice.question: What was Thomas Jefferson's role in the creation of the Declaration of Independence?

options.label: A
options.text: He was one of the five authors, but did not contribute significantly to the document.

options.label: B
options.text: He was the primary author of the document, but did not include a clause opposing the slave trade.

options.label: C
options.text: He was the primary author of the document and included a clause opposing the slave trade, but it was removed by state delegates.

options.label: D
options.text: He was not involved in the creation of the Declaration of Independence.

multiple-choice.question: What was Thomas Jefferson's stance on slavery?

options.label: A
options.text: He was a strong advocate for the abolition of slavery and freed all of his enslaved people.

options.label: B
options.text: He recognized slavery as an immoral institution, but did not take significant action to combat it.

options.label: C
options.text: He believed that slavery was a necessary institution and worked to expand it.

options.label: D
options.text: He was neutral on the issue of slavery and did not express any opinions on it.

multiple-choice.question: What was the Indian Removal Act, and how was Thomas Jefferson involved in it?

options.label: A
options.text: The Indian Removal Act was a law that protected the rights of Indigenous Americans, and Thomas Jefferson was a key supporter of it.

options.label: B
options.text: The Indian Removal Act was a law that forcibly relocated Indigenous Americans, and Thomas Jefferson's recommendations formed the basis for it.

options.label: C
options.text: The Indian Removal Act was a law that provided financial support to Indigenous Americans, and Thomas Jefferson was not involved in it.

options.label: D
options.text: The Indian Removal Act was a law that established reservations for Indigenous Americans, and Thomas Jefferson opposed it.

multiple-choice.question: How did Thomas Jefferson's relationship with Sally Hemings reflect his views on slavery and racial equality?

options.label: A
options.text: His relationship with Sally Hemings showed that he was committed to racial equality and opposed slavery.

options.label: B
options.text: His relationship with Sally Hemings was a secret, and he continued to publicly denounce the personhood of Black Americans.

options.label: C
options.text: His relationship with Sally Hemings was a public statement against slavery, and he freed all of his enslaved people as a result.

options.label: D
options.text: His relationship with Sally Hemings had no impact on his views on slavery and racial equality.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the criticisms of Thomas Jefferson's presidency?

options.label: A
options.text: He did not expand the country's territory enough.

options.label: B
options.text: He did not work to prevent the country from taking on too much debt.

options.label: C
options.text: He won the presidency due to a system that gave states that held people in slavery additional voting power in the Electoral College.

options.label: D
options.text: He did not lead the US through the Napoleonic and Barbary Wars successfully.

title: What sex ed doesn’t tell you about your brain - Shannon Odell

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.text: Estrogen and testosterone

options.label: D
options.text: Dopamine and serotonin

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To process sensory information

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: To process sensory information

options.label: C
options.text: To control movement and coordination

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: Until the mid-teens

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: You don't actually know what your future self wants - Shankar Vendantam

multiple-choice.question: What is the "illusion of continuity" that the speaker refers to?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea that our past and present selves are the same person.

options.label: B
options.text: The idea that our future selves will be the same as our present selves.

options.label: C
options.text: The idea that we can predict our future with certainty.

options.label: D
options.text: The idea that we are always changing and growing.

multiple-choice.question: What is the story of John and Stephanie Rinka used to illustrate?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of advance directives in end-of-life care.

options.label: B
options.text: The challenges of making decisions for a loved one with a terminal illness.

options.label: C
options.text: The illusion of continuity and how our preferences and values can change over time.

options.label: D
options.text: The importance of staying curious and trying new things.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "ship of Theseus" thought experiment used to illustrate?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea that our bodies are constantly changing and replacing cells.

options.label: B
options.text: The idea that our psychological selves are constantly changing and evolving.

options.label: C
options.text: The idea that we are the same person throughout our lives.

options.label: D
options.text: The idea that we can predict our future with certainty.

multiple-choice.question: What is the first piece of advice the speaker offers for wrestling with the illusion of continuity?

options.label: A
options.text: Stay curious and try new things.

options.label: B
options.text: Practice humility and recognize that our views may change over time.

options.label: C
options.text: Be brave and take risks.

options.label: D
options.text: Make a plan and stick to it.

multiple-choice.question: What is the third piece of advice the speaker offers for wrestling with the illusion of continuity?

options.label: A
options.text: Stay curious and try new things.

options.label: B
options.text: Practice humility and recognize that our views may change over time.

options.label: C
options.text: Be brave and recognize that our future selves may have capacities and strengths we don't possess today.

options.label: D
options.text: Make a plan and stick to it.

title: Is it possible to lose weight fast? - Hei Man Chan

multiple-choice.question: What was the tapeworm diet that was popular in Victorian England?

options.label: A
options.text: A diet that involved consuming tapeworms as a source of protein

options.label: B
options.text: A diet that involved swallowing an unhatched tapeworm and letting it grow inside the body

options.label: C
options.text: A diet that involved eating foods that were high in fiber to reduce hunger

options.label: D
options.text: A diet that involved drinking a special tea to boost metabolism

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the body when it goes into a starvation response, like Felix's body did when he dramatically cut his calorie intake?

options.label: A
options.text: The body starts burning fat cells as a major energy source

options.label: B
options.text: The body breaks down its entire store of emergency glucose and starts breaking down other materials, including muscles

options.label: C
options.text: The body starts storing more glycogen in the liver

options.label: D
options.text: The body's metabolism slows down to conserve energy

multiple-choice.question: Why might Felix think he's losing weight fast on his low-calorie diet, even though he's not actually losing fat?

options.label: A
options.text: Because he's losing muscle mass

options.label: B
options.text: Because he's burning more calories than ever before

options.label: C
options.text: Because every gram of glycogen is bound to several grams of water, which is lost when the glycogen is depleted

options.label: D
options.text: Because he's eating more frequently

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential problem with detoxification diets that promote or restrict certain foods to provide specific nutrients in high quantities?

options.label: A
options.text: They can be too expensive to follow

options.label: B
options.text: They can be too time-consuming to prepare

options.label: C
options.text: They can be too specific to be used as general cure-alls and may not account for individual nutritional needs

options.label: D
options.text: They can be too boring to stick to

multiple-choice.question: What is a key characteristic of a healthy dietary lifestyle, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It involves cutting calories drastically to lose weight fast

options.label: B
options.text: It involves restricting certain food groups to provide specific nutrients

options.label: C
options.text: It is sustainable and takes into account genetic and medical differences

options.label: D
options.text: It involves following a specific diet or meal plan for a short period of time
